DataElement.preferredDefinition: An explanation that describes the reason for the infusion delay and/or cancellation.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord._Time during which some action is awaited; inactivity resulting in something being put off until a later time; the state of being slower or later._Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid._Postpone indefinitely or annul something that was scheduled._An explanation of the cause of some phenomenon or action.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream. Also called intravenous infusion.

Concepts.definition: Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.

Concepts.definition: There was no excuse provided.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

PermissibleValues.value: Failure to mobilize / inability to collect adequate number of hematopoietic stem cells
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Stem Cell Mobilization Therapy Failure Or Unable to Perform Sufficient Quantity Hematopoietic Stem Cell

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Stem Cell Mobilization Therapy Failure Or Unable to Perform Sufficient Quantity Hematopoietic Stem Cell
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Therapy to cause release of stem cells from the bone marrow into the peripheral blood circulation for the purpose of collection.: A lack of occurrence or performance.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: An indication that an action, task, or function was not done due to a lack of skill, means, or opportunity.: Meeting a quantitative or qualitative measure necessary for a requirement; enough to meet the needs of a situation.: How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number.: Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)

Concepts.definition: Therapy to cause release of stem cells from the bone marrow into the peripheral blood circulation for the purpose of collection.
A lack of occurrence or performance.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
An indication that an action, task, or function was not done due to a lack of skill, means, or opportunity.
Meeting a quantitative or qualitative measure necessary for a requirement; enough to meet the needs of a situation.
How much there is of something that you can measure; the total amount or number.

Primitive blood cells derived from embryonic mesenchyme capable of differentiating into any of the blood cell line progenitor cells (erythroblasts, young granulocytic series cells, megakaryocytes, etc.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The desired information is not available.: Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.

Concepts.definition: The desired information is not available.
Someone who gives blood or tissue or an organ to be used in another person.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The return of a disease after a period of remission.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: The worsening of a disease over time.

Concepts.definition: The return of a disease after a period of remission.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A human being.: The cessation of life.

Concepts.definition: A human being.
The cessation of life.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A human being.: Used to describe the possession, relationships, or the state of something or someone.: The invasion of an organism's body tissues by disease-causing agents and their multiplication, as well as the reaction by the host to these organisms and/or toxins that the organisms produce.

Concepts.definition: A human being.
Used to describe the possession, relationships, or the state of something or someone.
The invasion of an organism's body tissues by disease-causing agents and their multiplication, as well as the reaction by the host to these organisms and/or toxins that the organisms produce.

PermissibleValues.value: Patient sent to hospice or receiving palliative care only

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A human being.: An establishment that provides palliative and supportive care for terminally ill patients and their families via physical, psychological, social and other forms of care.: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.: The patient- and family-centered active holistic care of patients with advanced, progressive disease. Essential components of palliative care are: pain and symptom control, communication regarding treatment and alternatives, prognosis, and available services, rehabilitation services, care that addresses treatment and palliative concerns, intellectual, emotional, social, and spiritual needs, terminal care, support in bereavement. The goal of palliative care is an achievement of the best quality of life for patients and their families.

Concepts.definition: A human being.
An establishment that provides palliative and supportive care for terminally ill patients and their families via physical, psychological, social and other forms of care.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

The patient- and family-centered active holistic care of patients with advanced, progressive disease. Essential components of palliative care are: pain and symptom control, communication regarding treatment and alternatives, prognosis, and available services, rehabilitation services, care that addresses treatment and palliative concerns, intellectual, emotional, social, and spiritual needs, terminal care, support in bereavement. The goal of palliative care is an achievement of the best quality of life for patients and their families.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A human being.: A unique macroscopic (gross) anatomic structure that performs specific functions. It is composed of various tissues.  An organ is part of an anatomic system or a body region. Representative examples include the heart, lung, liver, spleen, and uterus.: The normal action performed by a structure or device.: Made less in size or amount or degree.

Concepts.definition: A human being.

A unique macroscopic (gross) anatomic structure that performs specific functions. It is composed of various tissues.  An organ is part of an anatomic system or a body region. Representative examples include the heart, lung, liver, spleen, and uterus.
The normal action performed by a structure or device.
Made less in size or amount or degree.
